definition: deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected

definition: not harmful or offensive

examples: harried reporters are frequently forced to invent what they cannot find out

definition: having or showing great knowledge or learning
examples: she was very erudite
Ken could turn any conversation into an erudite discussion

definition: lasting only for a short time; impermanent
examples: a transient cold spell

definition: a person who is staying or working in a place for a short time only.
not influenced by strong emotion, and so able to be rational and impartial
examples: she dealt with life's disasters in a calm, dispassionate way

definition: showing or suffering from nervousness or a lack of confidence
examples: a timorous voice

definition: the expression of disapproval or disappointment
examples: he gave her a look of reproach
a farrago of warnings and pained reproaches

definition: express to (someone) one's disapproval of or disappointment in their actions
examples: ‘You know that isn't true,’ he reproached her
her friends reproached her for not thinking enough about her family

synonyms: give someone a piece of one's mind

definition: with an attitude or look of suspicion or disapproval
examples: a waiter looked askance at his jeans
the reformers looked askance at the mystical tradition

synonyms: out of the corner of one's eye

definition: not showing care for the consequences of an action; rash
examples: it would be imprudent to leave her winter coat behind

definition: contemptibly lacking in courage; cowardly
examples: a craven abdication of his moral duty

definition: a cowardly person.
evoke or draw out (a reaction, answer, or fact) from someone
examples: I tried to elicit a smile from Joanna
the work elicited enormous public interest

definition: not in keeping with good taste and propriety; improper
examples: a pub crawl with sundry indecorous adventures

definition: pacify or placate (someone) by acceding to their demands
examples: amendments have been added to appease local pressure groups

definition: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring
examples: an arduous journey

definition: bad-tempered and sulky
examples: a sullen pout

definition: a sulky or depressed mood.
cheerful and friendly
examples: she was in a jovial mood

definition: intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest
examples: esoteric philosophical debates

definition: the action or process of flowing or flowing out
examples: the flux of ions across the membrane

definition: treat (a metal object) with a flux to promote melting.
superficially plausible, but actually wrong
examples: a specious argument

definition: a subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound
examples: he was familiar with the nuances of the local dialect

definition: give nuances to
examples: the effect of the music is nuanced by the social situation of listeners

definition: interpret (a person's words or actions) wrongly
examples: my advice was deliberately misconstrued

definition: an expression of sharp disapproval or criticism
examples: he hadn't meant it as a rebuke, but Neil flinched

definition: express sharp disapproval or criticism of (someone) because of their behaviour or actions
examples: she had rebuked him for drinking too much
the judge publicly rebuked the jury

synonyms: give someone a piece of one's mind

definition: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame
examples: no other party risked ignominious defeat

definition: something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected
examples: the apparent anomaly that those who produced the wealth were the poorest
the position abounds in anomaly
there are a number of anomalies in the present system

definition: the state of feeling remorseful and penitent
examples: to show contrition for his crime he offered to do community service

definition: a deep-seated feeling of aversion
examples: his fundamental antipathy to capitalism

definition: a long, thick pillow that is placed under other pillows for support.
support or strengthen
examples: the fall in interest rates is starting to bolster confidence

definition: a statement which is made on the assumption that it will prove to be true.
put forward as fact or as a basis for argument
examples: the Confucian view posits a perfectible human nature

definition: (of something inanimate or abstract) successful in producing a desired or intended result; effective
examples: this treatment was efficacious in some cases

definition: expressing contempt or disapproval
examples: permissiveness is used almost universally as a pejorative term

definition: a word expressing contempt or disapproval
examples: most of what he said was inflammatory and filled with pejoratives

definition: slow to act
examples: he had been dilatory in appointing a solicitor

definition: so surprised and confused that one is unsure how to react
examples: Henry looked completely nonplussed

definition: untruthfulness
examples: people publicly castigated for past mendacity

definition: make (someone) less angry or hostile
examples: they attempted to placate the students with promises

definition: very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail
examples: she dressed with fastidious care

definition: (of a leaf, feather, or other part) ending abruptly as if cut off across the base or tip.
shorten (something) by cutting off the top or the end
examples: a truncated cone shape
discussion was truncated by the arrival of tea

definition: lacking interest or excitement; dull
examples: his mundane, humdrum existence

definition: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something
examples: his polemic against the cultural relativism of the Sixties
a writer of feminist polemic

definition: causing harm or damage
examples: divorce is assumed to have deleterious effects on children

definition: (of regulations, requirements, or conditions) strict, precise, and exacting
examples: stringent guidelines on air pollution

definition: treating all rivals or disputants equally
examples: the minister cannot be impartial in the way that a judge would be

definition: unorthodox
examples: a maverick detective

definition: an unorthodox or independent-minded person
examples: he's the maverick of the senate

definition: spread (something, especially information) widely
examples: health authorities should foster good practice by disseminating information

definition: the fact or condition of being banal; unoriginality
examples: there is an essential banality to the story he tells
the banalities of contemporary celebrity culture

definition: given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour
examples: a capricious and often brutal administration

definition: inefficient or inept; clumsy
examples: both men are unhappy about the maladroit way the matter has been handled

definition: providing moral or intellectual instruction
examples: edifying literature

definition: great wealth or luxuriousness
examples: rooms of spectacular opulence

definition: threats, violence, constraints, or other action used to coerce someone into doing something against their will or better judgement
examples: confessions extracted under duress
